scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of ten account books belonging to Charles Herman Liebert. Born in Newport, Kentucky, of German-American parentage, he was the son of John A. Liebert, a cabinet worker speacializing in the manufacture of piano cases. The family lived in Cincinnati, but had moved across the river to avoid an epidemic. J. A. Liebert later experimented with the manufacture of cases for the then-new sewing machine. Charles was hired by the Singer Manufacturing Company to read and reply to its German correspondence. He remained with Singer for more than sixty years and was for many years chief cashier.

He spent his adult life in New York City, in the late 1880's marrying Adelheid Kammerrer, and residing at 143 East 62nd Street. He was active in the Deutsch Liederkranz and the New York Athletic Club. He died in 1936.
The following are some of the abbreviations used in the account books:
Fred: Frederick W. Liebert, Charles' son
M.K. or Marie: Marie Kammerrer, his mother-in-law
R.C.K.: Robert C. Kammerrer, his brother-in-law
R.L.H.: R. L. Herman, a friend
The papers were given to the university by Herman W. Liebert in 1948.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Herman Liebert was born in Newport, Kentucky in the 1850s. He was hired by the Singer Manufacturing Company to read and prepare replies to its German correspondence. He remained with Singer for more than sixty years and, for many years before his retirement, was chief cashier. Liebert passed all of his adult life in New York City and was active in several clubs. He died in 1936.
